title: Evaluating the Financial Factors Influencing Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health in Africa
abstract: arXiv:2402.14939v1 Announce Type: new  Abstract: The study investigated the impact of healthcare system efficiency on the delivery of maternal, newborn, and child services in Africa. Data Envelopment Analysis and Tobit regression were employed to assess the efficiency of 46 healthcare systems across the continent, utilizing the Variable Returns to Scale model with Input orientation to evaluate technical efficiency. The Tobit method was utilized to explore factors contributing to inefficiency, with inputs variables including hospital, physician, and paramedical staff, and outputs variables encompassing maternal, newborn, and child admissions, cesarean interventions, functional competency, and hospitalization days. Results revealed that only 26% of countries exhibited efficiency, highlighting a significant proportion of 74% with inefficiencies. translated_title: 评估影响非洲母婴儿健康的财务因素
translated_abstract: 本研究调查了医疗系统效率对非洲母婴儿服务提供的影响。使用数据包络分析和Tobit回归评估大陆上46个医疗系统的效率，利用变量规模回报模型和输入导向评估技术效率。Tobit方法用于探讨导致低效的因素，输入变量包括医院、医生和医务人员，输出变量包括母婴儿入院、剖宫产手术、功能能力和住院天数。结果显示，只有26%的国家表现出高效率，而有74%的国家存在低效率。发现的财务决定因素包括目前的健康支出、综合覆盖指数和人均目前健康支出。
tldr: 该研究评估了非洲母婴健康领域中财务因素对医疗系统效率的影响，并发现只有少部分国家表现出高效率，指出财务决定因素对此具有重要影响。
en_tdlr: This study evaluated the impact of financial factors on the efficiency of healthcare systems in the maternal and child health sector in Africa, revealing that only a small percentage of countries exhibited high efficiency and highlighting the significant influence of financial determinants.
